Thoughts are like cloudsâ€”they come and go, some light and beautiful, others dark and heavy.

But just like clouds in the sky, thoughts donâ€™t stay forever. The question is: which cloud will you focus on? 

I remember a time when my mind felt like a stormy sky. When I failed at something, dark clouds of self-doubt would fill my head. â€œYouâ€™re not good enough,â€ one would whisper. â€œEveryone will think youâ€™re a failure,â€ another would add. Iâ€™d get caught in the storm, believing every word. 

But then I learned to observe. 

Instead of fighting those dark clouds, I started watching them. Iâ€™d tell myself, â€œThis is just a thought. Like a storm cloud, it will pass.â€ 

And when I shifted my focus, I noticed something incredibleâ€”behind those storm clouds, there were always patches of blue sky, filled with lighter, hopeful thoughts. 

Hereâ€™s an example: 

When I started a new project, two clouds appeared in my mind. One said, â€œWhat if you fail? What if everyone laughs at you?â€ 

The other whispered, â€œWhat if this becomes the best thing youâ€™ve ever done?â€ 

For a moment, I stared at the dark cloud. It felt real. But then I chose to focus on the lighter one, the one filled with hope. That simple choice gave me the courage to take the next step, and that project became a turning point in my life. 

This practice of observing and choosing thoughts has changed everything for me. 

I still have stormy days, but now I know: I am the sky, not the clouds. The storms will pass, and the blue sky will return. 

If your mind feels cloudy today, pause for a moment. Look at the sky within. Let the dark clouds float by. Focus on the lighter ones. 

Youâ€™ll be amazed at how much clarity and peace this brings. 

Remember, youâ€™re not your thoughtsâ€”youâ€™re the one watching them. And that makes you limitless.

How to go viral on LinkedIn:

Start with a sob story that ends in a promotion.

Add a photo of a coffee mug to symbolize hustle.

End with 'If I can do it, so can you.'

But letâ€™s be real:

Not every day is inspiring.

Hustle culture is exhausting.

Hereâ€™s to sharing real stories, not just highlight reels.

Step 2: Wait a while.

Maybe companies should add 'emotional stability under rejection' as a prerequisite. ğŸ˜…

The Great Indian Parent Expectation-

Me: â€œI got a job!â€
Mom: â€œGovernment or private?â€
Me: â€œPrivate.â€
Mom: â€œTry UPSC.â€
Dad: â€œMBA kar le.â€
Relatives: â€œWhen are you getting married?â€

Jokes aside, we need to change this culture. 
Culture of "never being enough"

There's no end to it.
MBA
Shaadi
Bache
..

People say don't tell your goals to others.

I think a little differently.

I think, we should, so that their constant taane keeps us on our track.

So, here's mine for 2025 -
I want to try stand up comedy (open mic).

If I don't, please irritate me with your taane everyone!

Also, tickets le lena XD

Have you ever felt your heart race when you open your banking app? Or felt a lump in your throat when an unexpected bill arrives?

Youâ€™re not alone.

Financial anxiety is one of the most common, yet least discussed, struggles of modern life. It doesnâ€™t matter if youâ€™re earning â‚¹25,000 a month or â‚¹2.5 lakh â€” the fear of â€œWill I have enough?â€ spares no one.

Hereâ€™s the truth:

72% of millennials experience stress about money at least once a week.
Over 65% of professionals are living paycheck to paycheck.

Debt, emergencies, and societal pressure to â€œlive largeâ€ are only making it worse.

But no one talks about the sleepless nights. The constant calculations. The sacrifices we make, silently.

Why is this happening?

Social media glorifies luxury. Weâ€™re made to feel like weâ€™re failing if weâ€™re not jet-setting or dining at five-star restaurants.

A lack of financial literacy. Most of us were never taught how to manage money. We learned about trigonometry in school but not budgeting or investing.

The rising cost of living combined with stagnant wages.
What can we do?

Talk about it: Normalize conversations around financial struggles. Youâ€™d be surprised how many others are in the same boat.

Educate yourself: There are free resources, books, and courses on managing finances. Start small. Start now.

Set boundaries: Donâ€™t fall into the trap of societal FOMO. Your journey is yours alone.

Remember:

Itâ€™s okay to ask for help.

Your worth is not tied to your net worth.

Progress, no matter how small, is still progress.
To anyone struggling with financial anxiety, youâ€™re not alone. 

Letâ€™s create a safe space where we can support each other â€” without judgment or shame.

"Hurt people hurt people." 

When someoneâ€™s pain spills over onto youâ€”through harsh words, cold actions, or angerâ€”itâ€™s easy to feel confused or even blame yourself. You start to wonder: â€œWhat did I do wrong? Why are they treating me this way?â€

Hereâ€™s the truth: Itâ€™s not your fault.

When someone lashes out at you, speaks harshly, or makes you feel small, itâ€™s rarely about you. Most of the time, itâ€™s about their painâ€”pain they havenâ€™t been able to process, pain that leaks out in ways it shouldnâ€™t. 

The friend who distanced themselves for no reason? 
The partner who made you feel like you're not enough?

Chances are, theyâ€™re fighting battles you canâ€™t see. But let me remind you: Their wounds are not your responsibility.

Maybe they donâ€™t know how to process their struggles. Maybe theyâ€™ve never been taught how to ask for help. But even in their brokenness, you might still see their goodnessâ€”the version of them they could be if they allowed themselves to heal.

You didnâ€™t cause their pain, and you are not their punching bag. 

You donâ€™t have to fix them, and you donâ€™t have to carry the burden of their behavior. 

You can hold space for that. You can still love them while setting boundaries. You can still want them to heal while stepping back to protect your own heart.

Hereâ€™s what love looks like in these moments:

You forgive, not to excuse, but to free yourself from their pain.

You wish them healing, even from a distance.
You remind yourself that their hurt is not your responsibility to carry.

 And most importantly, remind yourself that someone elseâ€™s actions do not define your worth. 

And if youâ€™re the one hurting, struggling to let others in, remember: Thereâ€™s a version of you beyond this pain. People around you may want you to healâ€”not for them, but for you.

Weâ€™re all carrying something. Letâ€™s choose healing, for ourselves and for each other.
The cycle of hurt can end with us. Letâ€™s choose kindnessâ€”for others, but most importantly, for ourselves. 

If youâ€™ve ever been in this situation, know that youâ€™re not alone.
